text.p: The following are the main stories from Monday morning's German newspapers:
- Metal workers' employers and IG Metall union to meet on Monday to discuss controversial 20 percent cuts in sick pay permitted by change in German law last month.
- Peru author Mario Vargas Llosa wins Frankfurt book fair peace prize
- FDP party chairman Guido Westerwelle wants to make the liberal party a leader for reforms in all areas.
- Finance Minister Theo Waigel and FDP leaders criticise CDU income tax reform plan. Waigel says coalition did not agree with CDU plan to tax earnings from the sale of shares and property.

- Chancellery and Defence Ministry in row over funds for a spy satellite. Defence Ministry say the spy satellite system not a priority, while Chancellery strongly backs the proposed French-German satellite system.
- CDU politicians want to curtail so-called "training holidays" for workers.
- Several hundred protest in Hanover against Republican party convention. The protesters said the Republicans are dangerous because they encourage right-wing extremists.
- Telekom in negotiations with Leo Kirch group about cooperating in digital pay-TV arena.
- SPD opposes plans by Interior Minister Manfred Kanther for reform of financing pensions for public servants.
- Waigel says big effort needed to cut tax breaks as part of tax reform plans. Waigel says there should be no taboos when it comes to eliminating tax breaks.
- Waigel critical of proposed taxes on shareholders projects.
- German-language authors call for repeal of reform of the German language spelling rules
